Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental Investigation of the Electrical Properties of Hydrous Silicate Melts in Subduction Context
Award.AbstractNarration:
The dynamics and time-evolution of subduction are driven by mechanical and chemical processes that influence buoyancy forces, slab motion, contrasting thermal fields, phase equilibria, and volatile transport. By enhancing mass transfer and energy release, the cycle of fluids (and in particular, hydrous silicate melts) in subduction zones is a major component of slab recycling, arc volcanism, and continent-building processes. A better understanding of the role of melt and volatiles in subduction is therefore key to improving our knowledge of the structure and composition of subduction zones as well as geodynamic processes at work. It can also help us better assess volcanic and earthquake hazards in these contexts.

This project is a multi-disciplinary and multi-scale investigation of the electrical conductivity of hydrous silicate melts in subduction context, at the depth of the mantle wedge and shallower, in order to characterize and model the electrical response of hydrous melts in subduction zones. In situ electrical measurements will be performed at pressure and temperature conditions relevant to subduction zones on dry and hydrous silicate melts. The major objective is to understand better the transport properties of melts and volatiles in subduction zones as imaged by geophysical (electromagnetic) surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Field electromagnetic (EM) studies conducted across subduction zones in different parts of the world have identified several anomalies at depth next to the subducting slab. These electrically conductive anomalies are consistent with the presence of fluids (melt, aqueous fluids) following the breakdown of volatiles-bearing minerals in the slab and the partial melting of the mantle. However, if partial melting is easily identified using EM data (representing a large conductor at depth that is interconnected to smaller conductors at shallower depth below arc volcanoes, indicating melt upward migration), the presence of other conductivity anomalies at shallower depth is not well understood yet. In particular, it is unclear what phase(s) may cause these anomalies at a specific depth. The major objective of this project was to understand better the structure of subduction zones by investigating the stability and electrical properties of melts and volatiles (in particular, water released form hydrous minerals) as imaged by geophysical surveys. As explained below, we investigated the presence and fate of fluids in subduction contexts using geophysical, experimental and modeling tools.

We used electromagnetics surveys to investigate the location and pathways of fluids in subduction zones. Recent EM studies showed that subduction zones are always more complex than they appear at first glance. We reviewed these studies and proposed that regions where highly conductive anomalies are observed in the mantle wedge at depths of ~80-100 km are related to the subduction of an anomalous seafloor, either related to excessive fracturing of the crust, subduction of seamounts, or other ridges and areas of high relief. These features deform the seafloor prior to entering the trench, which allows extensive serpentinization of the mantle. The importance of seafloor topography as part of field electrical data interpretation had been previously completely overlooked. We also suggested that the large conductors may represent melts with higher contents of crustal-derived volatiles (such as C and H). This would imply locally higher fluxes of hydrogen and/or carbon into the mantle wedge, perhaps also associated with subduction of anomalous seafloor structures with greater degrees of hydrothermal alteration. 

Using electrical experiments up to 10 GPa on natural polycrystalline lawsonite, a hydrous mineral stable in subducted slabs, we showed that lawsonite dehydration could contribute to electrical anomalies observed in the Cascades by releasing aqueous fluid at a depth of about 50 km. The breakdown of blueschist‐lawsonite releases fluids causing the electrical anomaly (temperatures within the mantle wedge at this depth are too low for melting to be triggered). In cooler settings such as Japan, we suggested that lawsonite remains stable at this depth and can therefore carry water to higher depth, where it could potentially contribute to triggering partial melting.

To further the behavior of subducted volatiles at depth, and in particular carbon coming from sediments, a thermodynamic model of the Fe-Ni-S-C system at the Earth's upper mantle conditions was developed. It was shown that redox reactions at the boundary of subducted slabs represent a likely mechanism for changing the (Fe+Ni)/S composition of metal-rich sulfide liquids and precipitating deep diamonds. In the deep upper mantle, all carbon in depleted sources (10-30 ppmw C) can be stored in the sulfide liquid, and alloy and sulfide liquids host a significant fraction of the C in enriched sources (30-500 ppmw C). 

In parallel to these studies, we designed a new electrical cell for multi-anvil experiments that will improve future investigations of subduction zones by allowing the investigation of low-viscosity materials under high pressure and temperature conditions. It represents a new tool for the multi-anvil community and is available via NSF-COMPRES. 

This project provided training and professional development opportunities to an undergraduate student, a graduate student, a postdoc researcher and a lab manager at UCSD and strengthened collaborations with ASU, WHOI, UCSC. Our work has been shared with the scientific community through scientific meetings and peer-reviewed articles.
